name: Complete Black Repertoire
description: A unified Black repertoire covering ALL White first moves. Against 1.e4: choose between the solid Caro-Kann (1...c6) or the classical 1...e5 with full coverage of Wayward Queen attacks, Italian, Spanish, King's Gambit, and Center Game. Against 1.d4: the rock-solid Slav Defense. Against flank openings (1.c4, 1.Nf3, 1.g3, 1.b3, 1.f4, 1.b4, 1.Nc3): practical central responses. Train like a real game - you don't know what White will play!

tree.explanation: You are playing BLACK. Select White's first move to practice your response. This repertoire covers all major first moves you'll face in real games!

children.explanation: The King's Pawn Opening - the most popular first move! You have two main choices: the solid Caro-Kann (1...c6) or the classical 1...e5. Both are excellent!

THE CARO-KANN DEFENSE! We prepare ...d5 to challenge White's center. The key idea: keep the light-squared bishop FREE by playing c6 before e6. This shares DNA with the Slav - same pawn structure, same bishop development!
White builds the ideal pawn center.
We challenge the center! Now White must choose: Advance (e5), Exchange (exd5), or Classical (Nc3/Nd2).
THE ADVANCE VARIATION! White gains space but creates a fixed structure. Our plan: develop bishop to f5 BEFORE e6!
THE KEY MOVE! Bishop outside the pawn chain. This is the whole point of the Caro-Kann!
White develops.
NOW we play e6 - bishop is already out! Solid position.
White develops.
Strike at the center! We undermine White's pawn chain.
White develops, eyeing the bishop.
Solid structure.
The Bayonet Attack! Aggressive but loosening.
We retreat. The bishop is safe and well-placed.
The Exchange Variation. White releases the tension.
We recapture with the pawn. Symmetric structure, easy equality.
White develops.
We develop. Easy game ahead!
The Panov Attack! White creates an IQP position.
We develop. Standard IQP positions ahead.
The Classical Variation. White defends e4.
We take! Now 4.Nxe4 is forced.
White recaptures.
THE MAIN LINE! Bishop out before e6. This is our key plan.
White attacks the bishop.
We retreat. Solid and good!
The Karpov Variation - very solid.
Early queen out - even worse against the Caro-Kann! No targets here.
Just continue with our plan! The queen has no good targets. After 3.e5 we play Bf5 as usual.
Another weak early queen move.
Keep playing normal moves! We're fine.

THE OPEN GAME! We mirror White's central control. This leads to classical positions - Italian, Spanish, King's Gambit. WARNING: Watch out for early queen attacks (2.Qh5, 2.Qf3) - we have complete coverage!

THE WAYWARD QUEEN ATTACK (also called Parham Attack)! White threatens Qxe5+ and the 'Scholar's Mate' pattern with Qxf7#. DON'T PANIC! This is actually a BAD move - the queen is out too early and we'll attack it while developing.
THE KEY MOVE! We defend e5 AND develop a piece. Now White's queen is awkwardly placed. Notice we DON'T play 2...Qe7 (blocks our bishop) or panic with weird moves.
White sets up the Scholar's Mate threat (Qxf7#). This is the classic beginner trap!
THE REFUTATION! We kick the queen AND prepare to fianchetto. The queen has NO good squares!
White retreats, still eyeing f7.
We develop WITH TEMPO - attacking the queen AGAIN! This is the whole strategy: every queen move = we develop a piece.
White retreats again, attacking f7 and b7.
BRILLIANT! We attack the queen AND threaten Nxc2+ forking king and rook! White is in serious trouble.
White tries a desperate sacrifice.
We step into the center! The king is safe here and we're winning material.
White tries to save the bishop.
We attack the queen! After Qd3 or Qc3, we play ...Kxf7 and Black is winning - extra pawn, huge development lead, and White's queen has moved 5 times!
White retreats again.
We take the bishop! Black is WINNING: extra pawn, massive development lead (3 pieces vs 0), and the king is perfectly safe. White's queen moved 5 times to achieve nothing!
White defends c2.
We PIN the queen to the king! Black is winning.
White takes the bishop.
FORK! We win the rook! Black is completely winning.
Forced.
We've won the rook! Black is completely winning with material advantage and superior development.
Alternative - complete the fianchetto. Also excellent.
A GREEDY BLUNDER! White takes the pawn but...
THE QUEEN IS TRAPPED! There's no escape. Na5 traps it, and ...Rb8 is coming. Black wins the queen!
White tries to escape.
TRAPPED! The queen has nowhere to go. Black wins the queen!
Also wins! The queen is trapped.
White tries another escape.
Fork! We win material regardless.
White finally develops.
We castle! Black has a HUGE lead in development. We have 3 pieces developed and castled, White has only the queen out (which has moved 4 times!) and one knight.
White retreats to e2.
We complete development. Huge advantage for Black.
White retreats all the way back. Embarrassing!
We develop! Black has a HUGE advantage - White wasted two moves with the queen while we developed perfectly.
White develops.
We develop. Black is way ahead in development - 3 pieces vs 1!
White retreats to e2.
We fianchetto! Beautiful development.
White retreats but stays active.
We develop and threaten ...Nxe4 attacking the queen!
White defends e4.
We develop! Excellent position.
White retreats to h3.
We develop! The queen on h3 is doing nothing useful.
A MISTAKE! This blocks our bishop and is passive. DON'T defend with your queen - use PIECES!
ANOTHER MISTAKE! Don't bring YOUR queen out to defend - use pieces! This blocks the f6 square for the knight.
A MISTAKE! This blocks f7 but puts the knight on a bad square. Use 3...g6! instead.
White takes the pawn with check. This wins a pawn but loses time!
We block and DEVELOP! Now the queen must move again. We're down a pawn but have MASSIVE compensation.
White retreats.
We develop, attacking e4! The compensation is enormous.
White defends e4.
We strike in the center! Opening lines for our pieces. Black has excellent compensation for the pawn.
White takes.
We castle and let them have the pawn! Our lead in development is crushing. The rook comes to e8 next.
White retreats.
We develop! Great compensation.
BAD! This blocks the bishop. Always use PIECES to block, not the queen!
White retreats immediately without Bc4.
We develop WITH TEMPO! Attacking the queen.
White attacks f7 and b7.
Same idea! Attacking queen and threatening Nxc2+. If Qd3, then ...Nf5 is excellent.
White retreats.
The knight retreats to a great square! Black has a big advantage.
White develops with threats.
We strike in the center! Attacking both bishop and e4.
White takes.
We develop with tempo! Attacking the queen. Black has excellent play.
White retreats to h4.
We develop! The queen on h4 is exposed.
White plays.
We threaten to trap the queen with ...g5! if the queen doesn't retreat.
Alternative - counter-attack e4! Also good but Nc6 is more solid and easier to play.
White wins the pawn.
We block and develop. Excellent compensation!
THE NAPOLEON ATTACK! White aims for Scholar's Mate (Bc4 + Qxf7#). Same ideas apply - develop with tempo!
We defend e5 and develop! Same philosophy as against Qh5.
White threatens Qxf7#.
We defend f7 AND attack e4! Perfect development.
White defends e4.
We attack the bishop! Gaining more tempo.
White retreats.
We trade! Ruining White's pawn structure.
White recaptures.
We develop! Black has a great position - better development and White has doubled pawns.
White recaptures this way.
We develop! Excellent position for Black.
A DESPERATE SACRIFICE! White hopes for tricks but it just loses material.
We take! The king is safe and we're winning.
White checks.
We block and open lines for our pieces! Black is winning - up a piece!
White retreats.
We develop! Black has a clear advantage.
Alternative - pin the knight! Also excellent.
White attacks our bishop and knight.
We take! Now exd5 loses the bishop to ...Qh4+!
A BLUNDER!
DOUBLE ATTACK! Threatening Qxf2# and Qxc4. Black wins material!
Better for White.
We castle! Black has a comfortable position.
White develops.
We solidify. Excellent position.
White retreats, threatening e5.
We defend e5 solidly. Black has a clear advantage.
White defends e4.
We develop! Black has a big advantage - queen on f3 is misplaced.
BAD! Blocks the bishop, passive. Never defend with your queen when pieces will do!
White develops normally.
We develop. Black is already better - White's queen is misplaced on f3.
Another early queen move - attacking g7. Very weak!
We attack the queen while developing! Perfect.
GREEDY BLUNDER! White takes the pawn but gets the queen trapped!
THE QUEEN IS TRAPPED! There's no escape. Black wins the queen for a rook!
The only square, but...
We win the g2 pawn and threaten the f2 pawn. Black is completely winning!
White retreats.
We develop! Black has a big lead already.
White retreats.
We strike the center! Excellent play.
The Bishop's Opening - can transpose to Scholar's Mate attempts.
We attack e4! The best response.
White defends e4 with the queen and threatens Qxf7#.
We defend e5 and develop! The queen is awkwardly placed.
White prepares d4.
We attack the bishop! Gaining more tempo.
White retreats.
We win a pawn! The queen moved too many times.
White brings out the queen anyway!
We defend e5. Same ideas - attack the queen with development!
White takes the pawn.
We develop! Great compensation.
Normal play.
We develop! Standard Italian-like position.
Also good - defending e5.
White goes for Scholar's Mate!
We kick the queen! Same refutation as the main line.
Napoleon Attack via Bc4.
We defend f7 and attack e4! Great position.
Normal development.
We develop normally.
A delayed queen attack. Strange but played sometimes.
We develop! Same ideas apply. The queen on e2 blocks the f1 bishop.
White plays solidly.
We develop! Black has a comfortable position.
Normal Italian Game setup.
We develop.
Also good - the Giuoco Piano.
The Ruy Lopez - completely normal, no wayward queen here.
The Morphy Defense - most popular response.
The Center Game - can lead to early queen activity.
We take the pawn!
THE CENTER GAME! White recaptures with the queen. The queen is out early but this is more respectable than Qh5/Qf3.
We develop WITH TEMPO! Attacking the queen. This is the key pattern - develop and attack!
White checks.
We block and develop! Perfect.
White develops.
We develop! Black has easy equality and good development.
Alternative - block with tempo! The knight attacks e4.
White retreats to a4.
We develop! Excellent position for Black.
White retreats all the way back. Embarrassing!
We develop! Black is clearly better - free tempo!
The Queen's Pawn Opening. We respond with the Slav Defense - rock solid and shares ideas with the Caro-Kann!
We contest the center! This leads to the Queen's Gambit complex where we play the Slav Defense.
The Queen's Gambit! White attacks d5.
THE SLAV DEFENSE! We defend d5 while keeping the bishop diagonal OPEN. Our plan: ...dxc4, then ...Bf5!
Natural development.
We develop and attack e4.
Main line - pressuring d5.
NOW we take! This is the key timing.
White prevents ...b5.
THE KEY MOVE! Bishop out before e6. Same idea as Caro-Kann!
White prepares to recapture on c4.
NOW we play e6 - bishop is already out! Rock solid.
Slow but solid.
We can develop the bishop immediately here!
White develops the knight first.
We develop. Same ideas apply.
The London System! Very popular at club level.
Solid development.
White solidifies.
We strike at the center! This is the key move against the London.
White supports d4.
We develop! Putting pressure on d4.
Flexible - could transpose to many systems.
We develop. If c4 comes, we play the Slav.
The English Opening! We respond with ...e5 or ...c5, grabbing central space.
The Reversed Sicilian! We grab the center.
White develops.
We develop. Solid position.
Natural development.
We develop! Black has a good game.
White fianchettoes.
We develop naturally.
The Réti Opening! Flexible - White delays central decisions. We respond with ...d5, grabbing the center.
We occupy the center! If White plays c4, we're in Slav territory.
The Réti proper - fianchetto setup.
We develop naturally.
White completes the fianchetto.
Our Slav setup! If c4 comes, we're prepared.
Transposing to English/Queen's Gambit ideas.
We play our Slav setup! Same ideas apply.
The Benko/King's Fianchetto. White plays flexibly. We grab the center!
We occupy the center! Solid and good.
White fianchettoes.
Natural development.
White develops.
Our Slav setup! If c4 comes, we're ready.
The Larsen/Nimzo-Larsen Attack. We respond classically.
We grab the center! The Bb2 will be blocked.
White fianchettoes.
We develop! Blocking the bishop's diagonal.
White prepares d4.
We develop! Black has a great position.
The Bird's Opening. Weakens the kingside. We respond actively!
We grab the center! Solid and strong.
Natural development.
We develop. Easy game.
The Sokolsky/Orangutan! Very rare. We respond classically.
We grab the center! The b4 pawn does nothing there.
White fianchettoes.
We develop normally. Black is fine!
Also excellent - grab the center!
The Dunst/Van Geet Opening. Blocks the c-pawn! We grab the center.
We occupy the center! Simple and strong.
White challenges the center.
We advance! Kicking the knight.
The knight retreats awkwardly.
Big center! Black is doing great.
